newsitem.title: FRANCE: Cannes throws star-spangled 50th birthday festival.
newsitem.headline: Cannes throws star-spangled 50th birthday festival.

text.p: The Cannes film festival will celebrate its 50th birthday next month with a thriller-heavy competition slate and awards ceremonies attended by the great and the good of the silver screen, organisers said on Tuesday.

Festival supremo Gilles Jacob told a news conference that Golden Palm candidates at the May 7-18 jamboree would include Johnny Depp ("The Brave") and Gary Oldman ("Nil By Mouth"), both first-timers in directing, and Wim Wenders ("The End of Violence") and Nick Cassavetes ("Call It Love").
After sifting through 860 films, Jacob's team picked 19 for the French Riviera resort competition judged this year by a jury led by French actress Isabelle Adjani.
But Jacob said his list was not closed and would welcome offerings from Constantin Costa-Gavras and Abbas Kiarostami if they were ready in time.
"Eight of the films in selection are thrillers, excluding "Hamlet" by Kenneth Branagh which I suppose I could include. These days people want violence, blood, gore," Jacob said.

American movies take the biggest share of the selection with six entries including Clint Eastwood's "Absolute Power" (shown out of competition) and Curtis Hanson's thriller "L.A. Confidential" based on a novel by James Ellroy.

France's spectacular-specialist Luc Besson kicks off the Cannes season with the futuristic "Le Cinquieme Element" (The Fifth Element). Jacob said he had not decided yet whether it would compete for the Golden Palm.

Other candidates include China's Zhang Yimou ("Keep Cool"), Italy's Francesco Rosi ("La Tregua"), Britain's Michael Winterbottom ("Welcome to Sarajevo"), Canada's Atom Egoyan ("The Sweet Hereafter") and France's Matthieu Kassovitz ("Assassin").

No Cannes festival would be complete without controversy, and critics are looking to a midnight screening of maverick Abel Ferrara's "Black Out" and his lascivious coupling of Claudia Schiffer and Beatrice Dalle to supply it.
To mark the 50th anniversary, virtually all the 35 surviving directors who have won the Golden Palm will attend the award of a special Palm of Palms to Sweden's Ingmar Bergman.

They include Michelangelo Antonioni, Robert Altman, Franceso Rosi, Francis Ford Coppola, Martin Scorsese, Emir Kusturica, Costa-Gavras, Wenders, David Lynch, Jane Campion, Chen Kaige and Quentin Tarantino.

Best actor prize-winners and other stars will also flock to Cannes: Robert de Niro, Bruce Willis, John Travolta, Kim Basinger, Michael Jackson, Gina Lollobrigida, Catherine Deneuve, Hugh Grant and Victoria Abril among others.

Culture Minister Philippe Douste-Blazy, attending the news conference the day after President Jacques Chirac called a May-June snap parliamentary election, said he did not know whether the head of state would stick by his earlier pledge to attend May 11 commemorations.
He said the state was giving the festival 22 million francs ($4 million) this year, the lion's share of its 30 million ($5 million) budget.
Both Oliver Stone's "U-Turn" and James Mangold's "Copland", widely tipped for Cannes, failed to make it in the end, officially because they were unfinished.
Asked about industry reports that "U-Turn" had been judged too violent, Jacob answered: "I did not see extracts from it but I have been told that there is a certain degree of violence...
"We cannot have an accumulation of violent film upon violent film in Cannes, because in the end it becomes unbearable."
